title: Worrying about work in the evening ‘could kill you’, experts warn
text:
Picture Rex More Most workers have had that moment, when they’re just putting their feet up – when the email from the boss arrives, and all the stress of the day comes back.
But worrying about work in the evenings – and taking work home – could have serious health effects, a new study has warned.
A study of 195 London office workers aged between 20 and 62 found that people who thought about work a lot in their free time had heart patterns associated with stress and anxiety.

Biobeats CEO David Plans, who worked on the study in Frontiers in Human Science, said, that taking work home is ‘killing people’ and that ‘it’s much worse than we thought.’
The volunteers wore fitness bands to track their heart rates – and answered questionnaires about how frequently they thought about work.
The researchers found that people who thought about work frequently in the evenings had scores which suggested they found it difficult to relax.
The scientists also found it was possible to flag up those neurons engaged in fear memory by over-producing a certain brain protein.
